items.title: Mother’s will in favor of Adam
items.summary: Mother died; will in Adam’s favor.
items.details: In September 2020, Adam’s mother died, leaving a will in his favor. In the following months he did not use the inherited property. The relatives raised no claims while his father was alive.

items.title: Father’s diagnosis; will in favor of Adam
items.summary: Father diagnosed with cancer; will already executed.
items.details: In April 2021, Adam’s father was diagnosed with late‑stage cancer. By that time he had already made a will in Adam’s favor.

items.title: Father’s death; international lawsuits filed
items.summary: Relatives filed lawsuits; lengthy claims (~100 pages).
items.details: In July 2021, Adam’s father died. Almost simultaneously, relatives filed international lawsuits contesting the parents’ wills. The claims ran dozens of pages (about 100) and were aimed at keeping Adam’s rights and assets blocked for as long as possible. Some claims were filed while the father was still alive but already incapacitated. On legal advice, Adam suspended transactions on his personal accounts.

items.title: Full asset freeze and restrictions
items.summary: Asset and movement restrictions in force.
items.details: Full asset freeze and movement restrictions were imposed, covering accounts and real estate. The freeze remains in effect.

items.title: Dispute over Adam’s apartment
items.summary: Sister refused temporary stay; dispute over eviction.
items.details: While in the United States for CAR‑T diagnostics, Adam contacted his sister, who was living in his apartment, asking to stay there temporarily. She refused, citing “discomfort.” Adam then stated that he no longer wished her to live there for free and asked her to move out. She refused, claiming that under the freeze Adam had no right to evict her.

items.title: Preliminary hearing scheduled
items.details: The court scheduled a preliminary hearing on the inheritance case for July 2024.

items.title: Hearing on the right to travel for treatment
items.summary: Consideration of permission to travel to the US; relatives objected.
items.details: The court considered granting Adam permission to travel for CAR‑T treatment in the United States. The relatives objected. A forensic medical examination was conducted.

items.title: Permission to travel for treatment granted
items.summary: Court authorized travel to the US for therapy.
items.details: The court granted Adam’s request and allowed him to travel to the United States for therapy.

items.title: Relatives’ visit; demand for medical examination
items.summary: Police intervened; restrictions imposed on the relatives.
items.details: Relatives came to Adam’s home insisting on taking him for a medical examination, citing a possible guardianship order. Adam objected, and the medical staff did not grant them access to him. Police intervened. The court held that such demands were unlawful without Adam’s consent and, as a sanction, imposed one month of custody on the relatives and a six‑month ban on entering the country for attempting to forcibly remove him from his home to an undisclosed location.

items.title: Eviction procedure against sister initiated
items.summary: Process started to evict her from Adam’s apartment.
items.details: In late June 2024, Adam initiated eviction proceedings against his sister after learning that she was the main initiator of the lawsuit. Earlier (in September 2021) she had refused him a temporary stay. Later she claimed in court that the eviction was unlawful, but the court found no violations.

items.title: Submission of documents; court fee paid
items.summary: Financial and medical documents submitted; $5,350 fee paid.
items.details: Before the preliminary hearing, Adam submitted financial documents on his accounts and medical materials, and paid a court fee of $5,350.

items.title: Preliminary hearing; two possible outcomes
items.summary: Court outlined two outcomes; settlement refused.
items.details: The court outlined two scenarios: (1) confirm the wills and secure the inheritance for Adam; (2) divide the inheritance among all children if pressure on the parents is proven. The relatives refused a settlement.

items.title: Motion to freeze relatives’ accounts
items.details: At the same hearing, Adam filed a motion to freeze his relatives’ accounts and review their financial transactions.

items.title: Relatives’ accounts frozen
items.details: The court granted Adam’s motion to freeze the relatives’ accounts to review their financial transactions.

items.title: Motion to unfreeze assets
items.details: Due to his health and a newly diagnosed form of leukemia, Adam moved for a full or partial unfreeze of assets, despite his lawyer’s opposition on the ground that such filings would only prolong the proceedings. Adam had no other option: he urgently needed funds because of the new form of leukemia and the uncertain scenario of upcoming treatment and maintenance of remission.

items.title: Hearing on the motion scheduled
items.summary: Court scheduled a hearing for November 2026.
items.details: In August 2025, the court accepted Adam’s motion for consideration and scheduled a hearing for November 2026.
